references.W02FARNAUS: Farquhar, C. Craig and Karen L. Ritchie. 2002. Black-tailed Gnatcatcher (Polioptila melanura), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/690

habitat_description:
The black-tailed gnatcatcher prefers semi-arid to desert scrub, typically in the lower Sonoran zone.  This species is one of the most common species in the Sonoran Desert and it's range extends east into Texas, and west into southern California (Farquhar 2002).

By and large, this species habitat preferences remain similar between the southwest and Great Plains regions. Typical associated species include creosote bush, Agave sp., salt bush, pickleweed, Mormon tea, Apache plume, and brickell bush. This species can be found on rocky slopes, desert washes, and may also inhabit very dense scrub while it forages for insects (Farquhar 2002).

The availability of water does not appear to influence it's distribution. Although this species was often noted to forage for insects near desert washes, it can also maintain permanent ranges over 3 miles from a watercourse (Farquhar 2002).

The black-tailed gnatcatcher's is known to be associated with many plant complexes and associations, but according to numerous sources, this species overall preferences is arid desert scrub (Natureserve 2009). B. Horton, 22jan10.
